citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is a widespread rodent infestation problem affecting the entire facility. Large accumulations of rodent feces were
found in numerous enclosures, as well as storage areas. A dead mouse was found in a drain inside the kennel building.
Evidence of a rodent nest was located in a central storage area which contained cleaning equipment. Rodent droppings
were found in a channel directly above kennels in numerous areas and the channel runs the entire course of the building.
Rodent droppings were found in a lighting fixture being stored above a kennel and located in the channel.
The license stated that due to financial issues the professional exterminator had not been employed for the last 60 days.
Exposure to rodents and rodent waste can have a severe impact on the health and well-being of all animals, but in
particular vulnerable animals such as puppies and nursing mothers. The facility uses different types of rodent bait stations
in an effort to control the problem, but these methods are clearly not adequate. Adequate pest control requires a systemic
approach and includes thorough cleaning and sanitization of all areas of the kennel, appropriate storage of food and
supplies, and preventing rodent access to the facility as much as possible. Bait stations alone are not sufficient for the
current situation.
An effective program for the control of insects, external parasites affecting dogs and cats, and birds and mammals that
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce
contamination by pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.11(d)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There is a widespread rodent infestation problem affecting the entire facility. Large accumulations of rodent feces were 
found in numerous enclosures, as well as storage areas. A dead mouse was found in a drain inside the kennel building. 
Evidence of a rodent nest was located in a central storage area which contained cleaning equipment. Rodent droppings 
were found in a channel directly above kennels in numerous areas and the channel runs the entire course of the building. 
Rodent droppings were found in a lighting fixture being stored above a kennel and located in the channel.  
 
The license stated that due to financial issues the professional exterminator had not been employed for the last 60 days. 
Exposure to rodents and rodent waste can have a severe impact on the health and well-being of all animals, but in 
particular vulnerable animals such as puppies and nursing mothers. The facility uses different types of rodent bait stations 
in an effort to control the problem, but these methods are clearly not adequate. Adequate pest control requires a systemic 
approach and includes thorough cleaning and sanitization of all areas of the kennel, appropriate storage of food and 
supplies, and preventing rodent access to the facility as much as possible. Bait stations alone are not sufficient for the 
current situation. 
 
An effective program for the control of insects, external parasites affecting dogs and cats, and birds and mammals that 
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce 
contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
